qas.question: What term does Popper use that roughly means verisimilitude?
Poppers notion of verisimilitude leaves no place for which kind of probabilities in the evaluation of scientific hypotheses?
What class of considerations did Popper believe were not important in scientific measurement?
What is the logical content of hypotheses inversely proportional to in Popper's reasoning?
What term means the opposite of verisimilitude?
What can never be evaluated as more or less true than another on an quantitative basis?
What does Popper emphasize has a lot to do with subjective probabilities?

context: Upon this basis, along with that of the logical content of assertions (where logical content is inversely proportional to <a3_0>probability<a3_0/>), Popper went on to develop his important notion of <b5_0>verisimilitude<b5_0/> or "<a0_0><b4_0>truthlikeness<b4_0/><a0_0/>". The intuitive idea behind verisimilitude is that the assertions or hypotheses of scientific theories can be objectively measured with respect to the amount of truth and falsity that they imply. And, in this way, one <b6_0>theory<b6_0/> can be evaluated as more or less true than another on a <b7_0>quantitative basis<b7_0/> which, Popper emphasises forcefully, has nothing to do with "<a1_0>subjective<a1_0/> probabilities" or other merely "<a2_0>epistemic<a2_0/>" considerations.
